chapters.title: The Privacymage's Preface / Why This Canon Exists
chapters.description: The frame and purpose: this spellbook tells WHY we're building (the second spellbook), while the First Person Spellbook tells WHAT (the first spellbook). Two canonsâ€”financial and socialâ€”diverged from one origin. Understanding the ancestry is necessary to wield the architecture.
chapters.proverb: The swordsman who knows not who forged the blade fights blind; the mage who knows not who wrote the grimoire casts hollow.

chapters.title: The Cypherpunk Whispers / Foundational Runes (1983-1997)
chapters.description: The first forgers inscribe the foundational runes: Chaum (blind signatures, pseudonymous credentials), May (Crypto Anarchist Manifesto), Hughes (Cypherpunk's Manifestoâ€”'privacy is the power to selectively reveal oneself'), Dwork/Naor/Back (proof-of-work). Privacy through mathematics, not permission. Cypherpunks write code.

chapters.title: The Early Incantations / Runes Before Synthesis (1997-2007)
chapters.description: The early mages attempt combination: Szabo (smart contracts, Bit Goldâ€”chained proof-of-work), Wei Dai (b-moneyâ€”peer-maintained ledgers), Davidson/Rees-Mogg (Sovereign Individual prophecy). All pieces present by 2005. The double-spend problem blocks all paths. The synthesis awaits.
chapters.proverb: The mages who came before did not failâ€”they inscribed the runes we still use today. The synthesis stands on their shoulders.

chapters.title: The Synthesis / When Protest Met Protocol (2008-2014)
chapters.description: Satoshi combines the runes: longest-chain rule solves consensus. Genesis block embeds political protest ('Chancellor on brink of second bailout'). Pizza transaction bootstraps economy. Mt. Gox teaches 'not your keys, not your coins.' But Satoshi knew: 'complete privacy is not possible' with this design. The privacy gap was acknowledged from birth. Satoshi vanishesâ€”reference loss as cryptographic act.

chapters.title: The World Computer / From Protest to Statecraft (2014-2016)
chapters.description: Vitalik expands from money to computation: Ethereum as generalized blockchain, Turing-complete, platform for unlimited applications. Wood's Yellow Paper formalizes. The unified myth briefly holdsâ€”financial and social technology as one. The DAO launches: $150M crowdfunded, governed by code. The dream of code as governance.

chapters.title: The First Fracture / When Code Met Social Consensus (2016)
chapters.description: The DAO is exploited via recursive withdrawal. Code did what it said, not what people meant. The community faces a choice: fork or accept. Ethereum forks to reverse the exploit. Ethereum Classic maintains original chain. The revelation: social consensus was always thereâ€”invisible, load-bearing. The community retreats from governance experiments. Privacy drops further down the priority list.

chapters.title: The Great Schism / Two Canons Diverge (2016-2022)
chapters.description: The financial canon pursues traction: stablecoins, DeFi, institutional adoptionâ€”economically meaningful but normatively thin. The social canon pursues depth: quadratic voting/funding, Network State, d/accâ€”normatively rich but lacking adoption. MakerDAO attempts synthesis but compromises. DeFi Summer and the casino critique. Neither canon addresses the missing primitive: privacy.

chapters.title: The Surveillance Truth / When The Watchers Learned to Read (2020-2025)
chapters.description: Chain analysis becomes a multi-billion dollar industry. Pseudonymity revealed as false privacyâ€”obscurity is not security. Tornado Cash sanctioned (Aug 2022): first time code itself was designated. Pertsev arrested: developer imprisoned for writing code, 'ideology of maximum privacy' cited as evidence. The contradiction: states welcome compliant crypto, oppose private crypto. Surveillance won the first round through defaults.

chapters.title: The Missing Primitive / Why Privacy Unifies Both Canons
chapters.description: Privacy enables the financial canon: real economic activity (payroll, treasury), front-running elimination, institutional adoption. Privacy enables the social canon: secret ballots, coercion-resistant voting, honest governance. Zero-knowledge maturation: 2010 (Satoshi couldn't use it) â†’ 2025 (production-ready). Privacy Pools: compliant privacy through association sets. Privacy is the foundation that unifies, not a feature to add.
chapters.proverb: The blade and the spell were always one weapon, separated by a missing rune. Privacy is not a feature to addâ€”it is the foundation that makes both canons whole.

chapters.title: The Open Canon / The Chapters Yet to Be Written
chapters.description: Three conditions for canonical completion: economically meaningful + crypto-native + normatively interesting (all three together). Past chapters written. Crucial chapters blank. Roles defined: Swordsmen (defend, build privacy), Mages (chronicle, project), First Persons (choose, delegate), Builders (code, deploy). Two futures: surveillance default or sovereignty default. 2-3 year window before architecture calcifies.

chapters.title: The Timeline Archive / Sources as Trust Graph Infrastructure
chapters.description: The archive is trust graph infrastructure: nodes (papers, posts, transactions, events), edges (citations, consequences, influence). Primary sources by era. Using the archive: verification, coordination, building, agent queries. Tending the archive: adding, correcting, resolving, maintaining. The archive is not ownedâ€”it is tended. Anyone can verify. Truth emerges from transparency.
